DESIGN

column2: yet familiar Sony design aesthetics. Featuring squarish corners with a slight curve at the edges of the glass screen (2D) to make holding/swiping more comfortable. Otherwise it’s a mostly flat screen.

column2: along with the majority of 2018 phones. As such
column3: the phone looks and feels smaller than a 5” 16:9 aspect ratio phone. This can be good or bad depending on preference. For example
column4: I’ve already noticed the keyboard is more cramped and overall feels tiny compared to every other phone I have. It’s certainly more than usable. If you’re going for a compact phone in the first place

column1: The backing is plastic
column2: but doesn’t feel cheap
column3: and does an good job of resisting fingerprints. Beyond that
column4: there is a USB-C port at the bottom and volume/power/camera button
column5: all on the right. And missing from many recent US Sony phones
column6: there is finally rear-mounted fingerprint reader.

column1: The single Nano-SIM and MicroSD tray is on the left. As an added bonus
column2: you can actually remove it with your finger nails. On the front you have a very useful notification LED. As well as my favorite feature
column3: front facing stereo speakers. As with most Sony phones
column4: they have a good high-end quality appearance and feel. But lean towards a more understated look. Nothing too flashy

column1: As is common these days
column2: the battery is not removable. It’s 2018
column3: so no surprise there. But I will continue to miss that particular feature.

column1: OS & FEATURES
Having owned Sony phones and tablets before
column2: everything feels very familiar. If you’ve recently used a stock android phone
column3: everything is generally where it should be. Minor changes include the app drawer
column4: which slides left/right
column5: and there are Sony tweaks hidden throughout. I keep finding nice touches here and there as I explore the UI.

column1: One noteworthy feature is the addition of Themes
column2: which are accessible with the Widgets & Wallpaper settings. Sony has their STAMINA mode which adds considerable battery life to the phone. It’s similar to what Google started adding since Marshmallow in that it disables extra functionality and features to really stretch out runtime. Most manufactures have some variant of this where it suspends inactive apps
column3: unless you exclude them. As in those cases
column4: be sure to “exclude” app you don’t want put to sleep (i.e. chat or messaging apps).

column1: Sadly
column2: there is a bit of bloatware in the form of Sony & few 3rd party apps
column3: which you generally can’t remove. For those you can disable/hide
column4: it’s easy enough to pretend they aren’t there. I just wish you could remove them all. Or not there to begin with.

column1: While I’m a big fan of 100% stock Android and faster updates
column2: I’ll gladly take the extras if basic performance & functionality doesn’t take a hit. Which is exactly the case here. There's enough usable and practical features that I like to make it worth it.

column1: At the time of this review
column2: we’re on Android 8.0.0 and Sony Build 51.1.A.4.173.

column1: PERFORMANCE
Stutter and lag are some of the most annoying things in a phone. I’ve sold phones for this reason in the past. As noted in the OS section above
column2: the user interface runs great. Unlike some manufactures
column3: Sony generally gives you just about all of the “flagship” specs on the small phones
column4: just as they do with the larger ones. So we’ve got a Snapdragon 845 with 4GB of RAM. Everything is smooth
column6: and no signs of stutter or lag.

column2: Anomaly KR
column3: Asphalt 8
column4: and many others. They all ran perfectly fine. It helps that we’re only needing to push 1080p.

column1: If pushed hard
column2: the phone does get a bit warm. In particular when going through the initial setup
column3: downloading a bunch of apps
column4: etc. That seems to be the norm with the latest high-end chips. Most of the time it’s rather cool.

column1: DISPLAY
After having used so many OLED displays
column2: it’s often difficult going back to a “normal” IPS LCD. However
column3: the 5” 1080p “HDR” Display on the XZ2 looks excellent. In fact
column4: right next to my OLED S8+ it more than holds it own. Solid black levels (if not quite OLED)
column8: etc. Colors can appear a tad over saturated at the higher brightness levels
column9: but there are display adjustments for that. Honestly
column10: it’s just a nice screen to look at it.

column1: With many cheaper IPS panels
column2: you really do notice lesser screen quality and poor black levels compared to the newer IPS/OLED displays. Not so here. Yes
column3: even with “only” 1080p resolution. On this 5” panel
column4: nobody is going to miss those pixels unless you have it right in front of you face. Sony has always been commended and known for good quality IPS panels
column5: and they continue to raise the bar. Default color temp leans toward the cool side. You can easily adjust this to your preference.

column1: Auto-brightness has improved over the years to the point where it’s useful. Adapting to your lighting condition and remembering your preference for different scenarios.
CAMERA

column2: the overall camera solution has been hit or miss on their own phones. Usually blamed on the software side of things. The 19MP front and 5MP rear camera are notable improvements over Sony phones in the past.

column3: it’s all better thanks to the external camera button that’s always there
column4: ready to open the camera app

column1: Unless you demand the best camera out there for 2018

column3: producing good overall images
column4: in the majority of situations. Not to mention putting older cameras to shame.

column1: VIDEO

column2: we have 4K video recording. Which looks good and is easily on-par with the Galaxy S8. There is HDR video recording that is rather unique to the XZ2 at this time. column3: but no video. This only became apparent when viewing later and I haven't been able to reproduce that yet.

column2: the relatively large 2870 mAh battery combined with the power efficient 845 chipset
column3: software improvements
column4: and 1080p display means you’ll likely get better than average battery life

column1: In my use
column2: I was seeing 5+ hours screen-on time

column3: however. Even I was using the phone much more than usual to stress test and see how the battery fares. The relatively smaller screen size combined with fewer pixels to push do help a lot.

column2: you’ll need to move up to the non-compact variant.

There are two speakers
column2: and they’re on the front. You know
column3: right where they should be. Fortunately

column3: vehicles

column1: FUNCTIONALITY

column1: There are other shortcomings also.  The removal of the auxiliary audio port is irritating - especially considering the XZ2 Compact is thicker than the XZ1 Compact.  Aux ports are NOT an obsolete technology
column2: this is something that is used!  Sometimes I don't want a bluetooth receiver on my head radiating my brain

column1: ERGONOMICS

The ergonomics are also a major step in the wrong direction when compared to the XZ1 Compact predecessor.  The screen is now much taller (see photographs).  This new size now prevents one-handed operation!  One-handed operation requires your pinky to balance and support the weight of the bottom of the phone
column2: your other three fingers to support and balance the back of the phone
column3: and your thumb to operate the touch screen.  But now your thumb will not reach the top of the screen due to the extra 1/2 inch of screen space.  And the top part of the screen that your thumb will not reach is frequently used - with back arrows
column4: pull down menus

column2: your pinky must move out of position.  Now nothing is supporting the weight on the bottom edge underneath the phone

column1: So naturally

column1: *Why Sony?*

column1: *Sony’s 2018 Lineup*
OK
column2: Now
column3: I'm going to compare the three most recent Sony models - the XZ2
column4: XZ2 Premium
column5: and XZ3. I don't know what Sony execs are smoking over there in Tokyo
column6: but they have decided to release these models within 6 months of each other - from April through October 2018
column7: respectively. So new stock is still available for all three. Why they chose to cannibalize themselves this way is beyond me. I can't imagine an XZ2 buyer being very happy with Sony releasing the XZ3 a bit less than 6 months after they plunked down for their current phone.

column1: All three phones share Sony's new ""Ambient Flow"" design language. This means they are round
column2: slippery
column3: shiny glass sandwich phones that have reduced bezels compared to their predecessors and a fingerprint sensor in the center of the rear of the phone body. All three share the ""Motion Eye"" camera sensor that excels at 960fps slow motion filming
column4: 4K HDR video
column5: and capturing bursts of moving still shots while staying in focus. All three utilize the Snapdragon 845 system-on-a-chip with Adreno 630 graphics. So they are all very capable 2018 Android flagships.

column1: The differences: The XZ2 has 4gb of RAM on board. It has an 18:9 IPS LCD display with a resolution of 1080x2160. The XZ2 Premium has 6gb of RAM
column2: a 16:9 4K IPS LCD screen at 3840x2160
column3: and a second monochrome camera module for improved low light performance. The XZ3 kind of splits the difference between the two. It has 4gb of RAM
column4: the same camera module as the XZ2
column5: but upgrades the 18:9 screen to a 6 inch HDR OLED display with a resolution of 1440x1880. Price wise

column1: So the $200 difference between the XZ2 and XZ3 all comes down to the screen. And I will say
column2: it is an absolutely beautiful screen. The blacks are as close to zero as they eye can see
column3: and the brightness for HDR video is spectacular. It also has the trendy curved side edges that you might like on the Samsung Galaxy line. But otherwise
column4: the XZ3 is functionally identical to the XZ2. It performs the same
column5: gets basically the same 1-day battery life (5-6 hours of screen on time)
column6: and takes identical pictures. I would say the price premium is only justified if you really prize the display and watch a lot of high quality video.

column1: The XZ2 Premium is a bit of a different beast. It does perform basically identically on Android tasks
column2: given the same internals. The 6gb of RAM seem to be dedicated to the camera
column3: which is the big differentiator. Adding the second low-light module to the camera does improve low light performance over the XZ2 and XZ3. It’s not night and day (so to speak) but the differences are clearly there upon close inspection. There is more detail and less noise on the XZ2 Premium’s low light photos. Its screen is the highest resolution of the bunch
column4: and it performs well with HDR video – though the XZ3 probably beats it with its deeper native contrast ratio. Now
column5: is this worth a $300 price premium over the XZ2? Personally
column6: I don’t think so. Given the choice of which one to use for free
column7: I’ll take the XZ2 Premium. But if I were doing the math on my own budget
column8: the XZ2 would be extremely tempting.

column1: *XZ3 Specific notes*
The XZ3 does also add a few new features
column2: almost all of which are superfluous. “Side Sense” brings up a shortcut menu when you double tap the curved edges of the screen. It is prone to misfires
column3: though
column4: so is more of an annoyance than anything. The phone also recognizes when you pull it out of your pocket and orient it in landscape
column5: and pulls up the camera. But since you still have to tap the screen to initiate the camera
column6: it really offers no benefit over the (wonderful) dedicated shutter button.

column1: The XZ3 is probably the prettiest of the three phones
column2: and is also the lightest. If you’re into comparing phones with your friends
column3: it is likely the one which will get the most “oohs and aahs” next to a Galaxy S9 or iPhone Xs.

column1: A case is an absolute necessity
column2: since the phone is so thin
column3: svelte
column4: and slippery. I almost dropped it several times before nestling it into its excellent Ringke Fusion X case.

column1: *Conclusion*

People who want to buy a Sony phone have been put in a hard spot by… Sony. It has released three similar flagship phones within 6 months. All three of the phones perform basically identically when it comes to speed. The XZ3 has the best screen. The XZ2 Premium has the best camera. Which of these three areas of performance you value most is how you should make your decision if a Sony phone is in your future. I frankly think the XZ2 will offer the best bang-for-buck for most users. It is also the model that is now best situated to compete with phones like the OnePlus 6T on price. Only those who seriously prioritize display or camera should consider the “step-up” models
